break-words light"><p data-start="0" data-end="167" class="">Awesome! Here are <strong data-start="18" data-end="61">50 AWS interview questions with answers</strong>, covering beginner to advanced levels and tailored for real-world usage, DevOps, and backend development:</p>
<hr data-start="169" data-end="172" class="">
<h3 data-start="174" data-end="193" class=""><strong data-start="178" data-end="193">Basic Level</strong></h3>
<ol data-start="195" data-end="1302">
<li data-start="195" data-end="317" class="">
<p data-start="198" data-end="317" class=""><strong data-start="198" data-end="214">What is AWS?</strong><br data-start="214" data-end="217">
<em data-start="220" data-end="317">Amazon Web Services is a cloud platform that offers on-demand computing resources and services.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="319" data-end="408" class="">
<p data-start="322" data-end="408" class=""><strong data-start="322" data-end="338">What is EC2?</strong><br data-start="338" data-end="341">
<em data-start="344" data-end="408">Elastic Compute Cloud – it provides resizable virtual servers.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="410" data-end="528" class="">
<p data-start="413" data-end="528" class=""><strong data-start="413" data-end="428">What is S3?</strong><br data-start="428" data-end="431">
<em data-start="434" data-end="528">Simple Storage Service – object storage with high availability, durability, and scalability.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="530" data-end="640" class="">
<p data-start="533" data-end="640" class=""><strong data-start="533" data-end="549">What is IAM?</strong><br data-start="549" data-end="552">
<em data-start="555" data-end="640">Identity and Access Management – it controls users, groups, roles, and permissions.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="642" data-end="749" class="">
<p data-start="645" data-end="749" class=""><strong data-start="645" data-end="674">What are Security Groups?</strong><br data-start="674" data-end="677">
<em data-start="680" data-end="749">Virtual firewalls controlling inbound and outbound traffic for EC2.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="751" data-end="845" class="">
<p data-start="754" data-end="845" class=""><strong data-start="754" data-end="770">What is EBS?</strong><br data-start="770" data-end="773">
<em data-start="776" data-end="845">Elastic Block Store – provides block-level storage volumes for EC2.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="847" data-end="965" class="">
<p data-start="850" data-end="965" class=""><strong data-start="850" data-end="896">What is the difference between S3 and EBS?</strong><br data-start="896" data-end="899">
<em data-start="902" data-end="965">S3 is object storage; EBS is block storage for EC2 instances.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="967" data-end="1059" class="">
<p data-start="970" data-end="1059" class=""><strong data-start="970" data-end="989">What is an AMI?</strong><br data-start="989" data-end="992">
<em data-start="995" data-end="1059">Amazon Machine Image – a template for launching EC2 instances.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1061" data-end="1180" class="">
<p data-start="1064" data-end="1180" class=""><strong data-start="1064" data-end="1107">What is the default region for AWS CLI?</strong><br data-start="1107" data-end="1110">
<em data-start="1113" data-end="1180">It depends on your config, usually <code data-start="1149" data-end="1160">us-east-1</code> unless overridden.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1182" data-end="1302" class="">
<p data-start="1186" data-end="1302" class=""><strong data-start="1186" data-end="1216">What is the AWS Free Tier?</strong><br data-start="1216" data-end="1219">
<em data-start="1222" data-end="1302">A usage limit that provides free services for new AWS customers for 12 months.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="1304" data-end="1307" class="">
<h3 data-start="1309" data-end="1335" class=""><strong data-start="1313" data-end="1335">Intermediate Level</strong></h3>
<ol start="11" data-start="1337" data-end="2464">
<li data-start="1337" data-end="1453" class="">
<p data-start="1341" data-end="1453" class=""><strong data-start="1341" data-end="1381">What is an Auto Scaling Group (ASG)?</strong><br data-start="1381" data-end="1384">
<em data-start="1387" data-end="1453">Automatically adjusts the number of EC2 instances based on load.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1455" data-end="1578" class="">
<p data-start="1459" data-end="1578" class=""><strong data-start="1459" data-end="1502">What is an Elastic Load Balancer (ELB)?</strong><br data-start="1502" data-end="1505">
<em data-start="1508" data-end="1578">Distributes traffic across multiple targets (e.g., EC2, containers).</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1580" data-end="1713" class="">
<p data-start="1584" data-end="1713" class=""><strong data-start="1584" data-end="1645">Difference between Application and Network Load Balancer?</strong><br data-start="1645" data-end="1648">
<em data-start="1651" data-end="1713">ALB works at Layer 7 (HTTP/HTTPS); NLB at Layer 4 (TCP/UDP).</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1715" data-end="1788" class="">
<p data-start="1719" data-end="1788" class=""><strong data-start="1719" data-end="1740">What is Route 53?</strong><br data-start="1740" data-end="1743">
<em data-start="1746" data-end="1788">AWS’s DNS and domain management service.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1790" data-end="1871" class="">
<p data-start="1794" data-end="1871" class=""><strong data-start="1794" data-end="1810">What is VPC?</strong><br data-start="1810" data-end="1813">
<em data-start="1816" data-end="1871">Virtual Private Cloud – your isolated network in AWS.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1873" data-end="2024" class="">
<p data-start="1877" data-end="2024" class=""><strong data-start="1877" data-end="1939">What is the difference between public and private subnets?</strong><br data-start="1939" data-end="1942">
<em data-start="1945" data-end="2024">Public has a route to the internet via an internet gateway; private does not.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2026" data-end="2123" class="">
<p data-start="2030" data-end="2123" class=""><strong data-start="2030" data-end="2056">What is a NAT Gateway?</strong><br data-start="2056" data-end="2059">
<em data-start="2062" data-end="2123">Allows instances in private subnets to access the internet.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2125" data-end="2215" class="">
<p data-start="2129" data-end="2215" class=""><strong data-start="2129" data-end="2152">What is CloudWatch?</strong><br data-start="2152" data-end="2155">
<em data-start="2158" data-end="2215">Monitoring and observability service for AWS resources.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2217" data-end="2314" class="">
<p data-start="2221" data-end="2314" class=""><strong data-start="2221" data-end="2244">What is CloudTrail?</strong><br data-start="2244" data-end="2247">
<em data-start="2250" data-end="2314">Tracks API calls and logs user activity for security/auditing.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2316" data-end="2464" class="">
<p data-start="2320" data-end="2464" class=""><strong data-start="2320" data-end="2381">What is the difference between CloudWatch and CloudTrail?</strong><br data-start="2381" data-end="2384">
<em data-start="2387" data-end="2464">CloudWatch: performance monitoring. CloudTrail: auditing/logging API calls.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="2466" data-end="2469" class="">
<h3 data-start="2471" data-end="2497" class=""><strong data-start="2475" data-end="2497">Storage &amp; Database</strong></h3>
<ol start="21" data-start="2499" data-end="2958">
<li data-start="2499" data-end="2609" class="">
<p data-start="2503" data-end="2609" class=""><strong data-start="2503" data-end="2526">What is Amazon RDS?</strong><br data-start="2526" data-end="2529">
<em data-start="2532" data-end="2609">Relational Database Service – managed SQL databases (MySQL, Postgres, etc).</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2611" data-end="2683" class="">
<p data-start="2615" data-end="2683" class=""><strong data-start="2615" data-end="2636">What is DynamoDB?</strong><br data-start="2636" data-end="2639">
<em data-start="2642" data-end="2683">A fully managed NoSQL database service.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2685" data-end="2790" class="">
<p data-start="2689" data-end="2790" class=""><strong data-start="2689" data-end="2729">Difference between RDS and DynamoDB?</strong><br data-start="2729" data-end="2732">
<em data-start="2735" data-end="2790">RDS is relational (SQL); DynamoDB is key-value NoSQL.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2792" data-end="2879" class="">
<p data-start="2796" data-end="2879" class=""><strong data-start="2796" data-end="2822">What is S3 versioning?</strong><br data-start="2822" data-end="2825">
<em data-start="2828" data-end="2879">Keeps multiple versions of an object in a bucket.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2881" data-end="2958" class="">
<p data-start="2885" data-end="2958" class=""><strong data-start="2885" data-end="2905">What is Glacier?</strong><br data-start="2905" data-end="2908">
<em data-start="2911" data-end="2958">Long-term archival storage in S3 at low cost.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="2960" data-end="2963" class="">
<h3 data-start="2965" data-end="2987" class=""><strong data-start="2969" data-end="2987">DevOps &amp; CI/CD</strong></h3>
<ol start="26" data-start="2989" data-end="3479">
<li data-start="2989" data-end="3088" class="">
<p data-start="2993" data-end="3088" class=""><strong data-start="2993" data-end="3018">What is CodePipeline?</strong><br data-start="3018" data-end="3021">
<em data-start="3024" data-end="3088">Orchestrates CI/CD pipelines for deploying code automatically.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3090" data-end="3182" class="">
<p data-start="3094" data-end="3182" class=""><strong data-start="3094" data-end="3117">What is CodeDeploy?</strong><br data-start="3117" data-end="3120">
<em data-start="3123" data-end="3182">Automates deployments to EC2, Lambda, or on-prem servers.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3184" data-end="3271" class="">
<p data-start="3188" data-end="3271" class=""><strong data-start="3188" data-end="3210">What is CodeBuild?</strong><br data-start="3210" data-end="3213">
<em data-start="3216" data-end="3271">Builds and tests your code in a scalable environment.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3273" data-end="3375" class="">
<p data-start="3277" data-end="3375" class=""><strong data-start="3277" data-end="3307">What is Elastic Beanstalk?</strong><br data-start="3307" data-end="3310">
<em data-start="3313" data-end="3375">PaaS to quickly deploy apps without managing infrastructure.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3377" data-end="3479" class="">
<p data-start="3381" data-end="3479" class=""><strong data-start="3381" data-end="3412">What is AWS CloudFormation?</strong><br data-start="3412" data-end="3415">
<em data-start="3418" data-end="3479">Infrastructure as Code – defines resources in YAML or JSON.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="3481" data-end="3484" class="">
<h3 data-start="3486" data-end="3519" class=""><strong data-start="3490" data-end="3519">Advanced/Enterprise Level</strong></h3>
<ol start="31" data-start="3521" data-end="4549">
<li data-start="3521" data-end="3600" class="">
<p data-start="3525" data-end="3600" class=""><strong data-start="3525" data-end="3541">What is ECS?</strong><br data-start="3541" data-end="3544">
<em data-start="3547" data-end="3600">Elastic Container Service – runs Docker containers.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3602" data-end="3691" class="">
<p data-start="3606" data-end="3691" class=""><strong data-start="3606" data-end="3622">What is EKS?</strong><br data-start="3622" data-end="3625">
<em data-start="3628" data-end="3691">Elastic Kubernetes Service – fully managed Kubernetes on AWS.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3693" data-end="3786" class="">
<p data-start="3697" data-end="3786" class=""><strong data-start="3697" data-end="3732">Difference between ECS and EKS?</strong><br data-start="3732" data-end="3735">
<em data-start="3738" data-end="3786">ECS is AWS-native; EKS is standard Kubernetes.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3788" data-end="3877" class="">
<p data-start="3792" data-end="3877" class=""><strong data-start="3792" data-end="3812">What is Fargate?</strong><br data-start="3812" data-end="3815">
<em data-start="3818" data-end="3877">Serverless compute engine for containers with ECS or EKS.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3879" data-end="4013" class="">
<p data-start="3883" data-end="4013" class=""><strong data-start="3883" data-end="3926">How does IAM role differ from IAM user?</strong><br data-start="3926" data-end="3929">
<em data-start="3932" data-end="4013">Role: temporary permissions for resources. User: credentials with fixed access.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4015" data-end="4123" class="">
<p data-start="4019" data-end="4123" class=""><strong data-start="4019" data-end="4054">What is an S3 lifecycle policy?</strong><br data-start="4054" data-end="4057">
<em data-start="4060" data-end="4123">Automates object transitions (e.g., to Glacier) or deletions.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4125" data-end="4214" class="">
<p data-start="4129" data-end="4214" class=""><strong data-start="4129" data-end="4156">What is a Bastion Host?</strong><br data-start="4156" data-end="4159">
<em data-start="4162" data-end="4214">Used to securely connect to private EC2 instances.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4216" data-end="4335" class="">
<p data-start="4220" data-end="4335" class=""><strong data-start="4220" data-end="4264">What is the Shared Responsibility Model?</strong><br data-start="4264" data-end="4267">
<em data-start="4270" data-end="4335">AWS: security <strong data-start="4285" data-end="4291">of</strong> the cloud; You: security <strong data-start="4317" data-end="4323">in</strong> the cloud.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4337" data-end="4440" class="">
<p data-start="4341" data-end="4440" class=""><strong data-start="4341" data-end="4369">What is Multi-AZ in RDS?</strong><br data-start="4369" data-end="4372">
<em data-start="4375" data-end="4440">Provides high availability by replicating the DB to another AZ.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4442" data-end="4549" class="">
<p data-start="4446" data-end="4549" class=""><strong data-start="4446" data-end="4478">What is Read Replica in RDS?</strong><br data-start="4478" data-end="4481">
<em data-start="4484" data-end="4549">Improves read performance by creating read-only copies of a DB.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="4551" data-end="4554" class="">
<h3 data-start="4556" data-end="4592" class=""><strong data-start="4560" data-end="4592">Security &amp; Cost Optimization</strong></h3>
<ol start="41" data-start="4594" data-end="5113">
<li data-start="4594" data-end="4675" class="">
<p data-start="4598" data-end="4675" class=""><strong data-start="4598" data-end="4618">What is AWS KMS?</strong><br data-start="4618" data-end="4621">
<em data-start="4624" data-end="4675">Key Management Service – manages encryption keys.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4677" data-end="4793" class="">
<p data-start="4681" data-end="4793" class=""><strong data-start="4681" data-end="4710">How to secure S3 buckets?</strong><br data-start="4710" data-end="4713">
<em data-start="4716" data-end="4793">Use bucket policies, block public access, enable encryption, use IAM roles.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4795" data-end="4898" class="">
<p data-start="4799" data-end="4898" class=""><strong data-start="4799" data-end="4831">What are Reserved Instances?</strong><br data-start="4831" data-end="4834">
<em data-start="4837" data-end="4898">Prepaid EC2 instances for 1 or 3 years at discounted rates.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4900" data-end="5004" class="">
<p data-start="4904" data-end="5004" class=""><strong data-start="4904" data-end="4930">What is Spot Instance?</strong><br data-start="4930" data-end="4933">
<em data-start="4936" data-end="5004">EC2 instances offered at a discount but can be terminated anytime.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5006" data-end="5113" class="">
<p data-start="5010" data-end="5113" class=""><strong data-start="5010" data-end="5040">What is a Trusted Advisor?</strong><br data-start="5040" data-end="5043">
<em data-start="5046" data-end="5113">Recommends cost optimization, performance, security improvements.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="5115" data-end="5118" class="">
<h3 data-start="5120" data-end="5150" class=""><strong data-start="5124" data-end="5150">Scenarios / Real World</strong></h3>
<ol start="46" data-start="5152" data-end="5767">
<li data-start="5152" data-end="5283" class="">
<p data-start="5156" data-end="5283" class=""><strong data-start="5156" data-end="5204">How would you migrate an on-prem app to AWS?</strong><br data-start="5204" data-end="5207">
<em data-start="5210" data-end="5283">Lift &amp; shift (EC2), refactor (EKS, Lambda), or containerize and deploy.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5285" data-end="5378" class="">
<p data-start="5289" data-end="5378" class=""><strong data-start="5289" data-end="5333">How to handle high availability for EC2?</strong><br data-start="5333" data-end="5336">
<em data-start="5339" data-end="5378">Use ASG across multiple AZs with ELB.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5380" data-end="5478" class="">
<p data-start="5384" data-end="5478" class=""><strong data-start="5384" data-end="5419">How to automate backups in AWS?</strong><br data-start="5419" data-end="5422">
<em data-start="5425" data-end="5478">Use AWS Backup, Lambda cron jobs, or RDS snapshots.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5480" data-end="5617" class="">
<p data-start="5484" data-end="5617" class=""><strong data-start="5484" data-end="5543">How do you monitor a microservices architecture in AWS?</strong><br data-start="5543" data-end="5546">
<em data-start="5549" data-end="5617">Use CloudWatch, X-Ray, Service Lens, and container-specific tools.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5619" data-end="5767" class="">
<p data-start="5623" data-end="5767" class=""><strong data-start="5623" data-end="5664">How do you ensure scalability in AWS?</strong><br data-start="5664" data-end="5667">
<em data-start="5670" data-end="5767">Auto Scaling, load balancing, decoupled architecture with SQS, serverless services like Lambda.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="5769" data-end="5772" class="">
<p data-start="5774" data-end="5912" class="">Need help with specific AWS services like EKS, CI/CD pipeline, or deployment examples for Spring Boot or microservices? light"><p data-start="0" data-end="192" class="">Perfect! Here's a curated list of <strong data-start="34" data-end="83">50 core Java interview questions with answers</strong>, grouped by beginner, intermediate, and advanced levels — especially useful for backend developers like you:</p>
<hr data-start="194" data-end="197" class="">
<h3 data-start="199" data-end="221" class=""><strong data-start="203" data-end="221">Beginner Level</strong></h3>
<ol data-start="223" data-end="1273">
<li data-start="223" data-end="321" class="">
<p data-start="226" data-end="321" class=""><strong data-start="226" data-end="243">What is Java?</strong><br data-start="243" data-end="246">
<em data-start="249" data-end="321">Java is an object-oriented, platform-independent programming language.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="323" data-end="414" class="">
<p data-start="326" data-end="414" class=""><strong data-start="326" data-end="346">What is the JVM?</strong><br data-start="346" data-end="349">
<em data-start="352" data-end="414">Java Virtual Machine — it runs Java bytecode on any machine.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="416" data-end="512" class="">
<p data-start="419" data-end="512" class=""><strong data-start="419" data-end="447">What is the JDK and JRE?</strong><br data-start="447" data-end="450">
<em data-start="453" data-end="512">JDK: Java Development Kit. JRE: Java Runtime Environment.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="514" data-end="636" class="">
<p data-start="517" data-end="636" class=""><strong data-start="517" data-end="549">What are data types in Java?</strong><br data-start="549" data-end="552">
<em data-start="555" data-end="636">Primitive (int, float, boolean...) and non-primitive (String, arrays, classes).</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="638" data-end="726" class="">
<p data-start="641" data-end="726" class=""><strong data-start="641" data-end="672">What is a class and object?</strong><br data-start="672" data-end="675">
<em data-start="678" data-end="726">Class: blueprint. Object: instance of a class.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="728" data-end="809" class="">
<p data-start="731" data-end="809" class=""><strong data-start="731" data-end="757">What is a constructor?</strong><br data-start="757" data-end="760">
<em data-start="763" data-end="809">A special method used to initialize objects.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="811" data-end="915" class="">
<p data-start="814" data-end="915" class=""><strong data-start="814" data-end="858">Difference between <code data-start="835" data-end="839">==</code> and <code data-start="844" data-end="855">.equals()</code>?</strong><br data-start="858" data-end="861">
<em data-start="864" data-end="915"><code data-start="865" data-end="869">==</code> checks reference. <code data-start="888" data-end="899">.equals()</code> checks values.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="917" data-end="1020" class="">
<p data-start="920" data-end="1020" class=""><strong data-start="920" data-end="951">What is method overloading?</strong><br data-start="951" data-end="954">
<em data-start="957" data-end="1020">Multiple methods with the same name but different parameters.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1022" data-end="1130" class="">
<p data-start="1025" data-end="1130" class=""><strong data-start="1025" data-end="1055">What is method overriding?</strong><br data-start="1055" data-end="1058">
<em data-start="1061" data-end="1130">Subclass provides a specific implementation of a superclass method.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1132" data-end="1273" class="">
<p data-start="1136" data-end="1273" class=""><strong data-start="1136" data-end="1201">What is the difference between static and instance variables?</strong><br data-start="1201" data-end="1204">
<em data-start="1207" data-end="1273">Static: shared among all instances. Instance: unique per object.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="1275" data-end="1278" class="">
<h3 data-start="1280" data-end="1306" class=""><strong data-start="1284" data-end="1306">Intermediate Level</strong></h3>
<ol start="11" data-start="1308" data-end="2364">
<li data-start="1308" data-end="1394" class="">
<p data-start="1312" data-end="1394" class=""><strong data-start="1312" data-end="1350">What are access modifiers in Java?</strong><br data-start="1350" data-end="1353">
<em data-start="1356" data-end="1394">public, private, protected, default.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1396" data-end="1507" class="">
<p data-start="1400" data-end="1507" class=""><strong data-start="1400" data-end="1426">What is encapsulation?</strong><br data-start="1426" data-end="1429">
<em data-start="1432" data-end="1507">Binding data and code together, restricting access using getters/setters.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1509" data-end="1609" class="">
<p data-start="1513" data-end="1609" class=""><strong data-start="1513" data-end="1537">What is abstraction?</strong><br data-start="1537" data-end="1540">
<em data-start="1543" data-end="1609">Hiding implementation details using abstract classes/interfaces.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1611" data-end="1700" class="">
<p data-start="1615" data-end="1700" class=""><strong data-start="1615" data-end="1639">What is inheritance?</strong><br data-start="1639" data-end="1642">
<em data-start="1645" data-end="1700">Acquiring properties and behavior from another class.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1702" data-end="1795" class="">
<p data-start="1706" data-end="1795" class=""><strong data-start="1706" data-end="1731">What is polymorphism?</strong><br data-start="1731" data-end="1734">
<em data-start="1737" data-end="1795">Ability to take many forms — overloading and overriding.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1797" data-end="1940" class="">
<p data-start="1801" data-end="1940" class=""><strong data-start="1801" data-end="1853">Difference between abstract class and interface?</strong><br data-start="1853" data-end="1856">
<em data-start="1859" data-end="1940">Abstract class can have state and constructors. Interface is purely behavioral.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1942" data-end="2021" class="">
<p data-start="1946" data-end="2021" class=""><strong data-start="1946" data-end="1988">Can an interface have default methods?</strong><br data-start="1988" data-end="1991">
<em data-start="1994" data-end="2021">Yes, from Java 8 onwards.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2023" data-end="2165" class="">
<p data-start="2027" data-end="2165" class=""><strong data-start="2027" data-end="2075">What is a final variable, method, and class?</strong><br data-start="2075" data-end="2078">
<em data-start="2081" data-end="2165">Final variable: constant. Final method: can’t override. Final class: can’t extend.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2167" data-end="2262" class="">
<p data-start="2171" data-end="2262" class=""><strong data-start="2171" data-end="2200">What are wrapper classes?</strong><br data-start="2200" data-end="2203">
<em data-start="2206" data-end="2262">Convert primitives into objects (e.g., int → Integer).</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2264" data-end="2364" class="">
<p data-start="2268" data-end="2364" class=""><strong data-start="2268" data-end="2304">What is autoboxing and unboxing?</strong><br data-start="2304" data-end="2307">
<em data-start="2310" data-end="2364">Auto conversion between primitive and wrapper types.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="2366" data-end="2369" class="">
<h3 data-start="2371" data-end="2403" class=""><strong data-start="2375" data-end="2403">Collections and Generics</strong></h3>
<ol start="21" data-start="2405" data-end="3555">
<li data-start="2405" data-end="2520" class="">
<p data-start="2409" data-end="2520" class=""><strong data-start="2409" data-end="2451">What is the Java Collection Framework?</strong><br data-start="2451" data-end="2454">
<em data-start="2457" data-end="2520">Set of classes/interfaces for working with groups of objects.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2522" data-end="2625" class="">
<p data-start="2526" data-end="2625" class=""><strong data-start="2526" data-end="2568">Difference between List, Set, and Map?</strong><br data-start="2568" data-end="2571">
<em data-start="2574" data-end="2625">List: ordered. Set: unique. Map: key-value pairs.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2627" data-end="2730" class="">
<p data-start="2631" data-end="2730" class=""><strong data-start="2631" data-end="2686">What is the difference between HashMap and TreeMap?</strong><br data-start="2686" data-end="2689">
<em data-start="2692" data-end="2730">HashMap: unordered. TreeMap: sorted.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2732" data-end="2854" class="">
<p data-start="2736" data-end="2854" class=""><strong data-start="2736" data-end="2784">Difference between ArrayList and LinkedList?</strong><br data-start="2784" data-end="2787">
<em data-start="2790" data-end="2854">ArrayList: fast random access. LinkedList: fast insert/delete.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2856" data-end="2947" class="">
<p data-start="2860" data-end="2947" class=""><strong data-start="2860" data-end="2882">What is a HashSet?</strong><br data-start="2882" data-end="2885">
<em data-start="2888" data-end="2947">Set implementation backed by a HashMap — unique elements.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2949" data-end="3055" class="">
<p data-start="2953" data-end="3055" class=""><strong data-start="2953" data-end="2983">What are generics in Java?</strong><br data-start="2983" data-end="2986">
<em data-start="2989" data-end="3055">Enable type-safe code using type parameters like <code data-start="3039" data-end="3053">List&lt;String&gt;</code>.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3057" data-end="3154" class="">
<p data-start="3061" data-end="3154" class=""><strong data-start="3061" data-end="3086">What is type erasure?</strong><br data-start="3086" data-end="3089">
<em data-start="3092" data-end="3154">At runtime, generics are erased and replaced with raw types.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3156" data-end="3286" class="">
<p data-start="3160" data-end="3286" class=""><strong data-start="3160" data-end="3221">What is the difference between Comparable and Comparator?</strong><br data-start="3221" data-end="3224">
<em data-start="3227" data-end="3286">Comparable: natural ordering. Comparator: custom sorting.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3288" data-end="3429" class="">
<p data-start="3292" data-end="3429" class=""><strong data-start="3292" data-end="3342">What is fail-fast vs fail-safe in collections?</strong><br data-start="3342" data-end="3345">
<em data-start="3348" data-end="3429">Fail-fast throws <code data-start="3366" data-end="3399">ConcurrentModificationException</code>. Fail-safe works on a clone.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3431" data-end="3555" class="">
<p data-start="3435" data-end="3555" class=""><strong data-start="3435" data-end="3472">How does HashMap work internally?</strong><br data-start="3472" data-end="3475">
<em data-start="3478" data-end="3555">Uses array + linked list (or tree after Java 8) with hashCode and equals().</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="3557" data-end="3560" class="">
<h3 data-start="3562" data-end="3584" class=""><strong data-start="3566" data-end="3584">Advanced Level</strong></h3>
<ol start="31" data-start="3586" data-end="4731">
<li data-start="3586" data-end="3677" class="">
<p data-start="3590" data-end="3677" class=""><strong data-start="3590" data-end="3625">What is multithreading in Java?</strong><br data-start="3625" data-end="3628">
<em data-start="3631" data-end="3677">Concurrent execution of two or more threads.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3679" data-end="3811" class="">
<p data-start="3683" data-end="3811" class=""><strong data-start="3683" data-end="3736">Difference between <code data-start="3704" data-end="3718">synchronized</code> and <code data-start="3723" data-end="3733">volatile</code>?</strong><br data-start="3736" data-end="3739">
<em data-start="3742" data-end="3811"><code data-start="3743" data-end="3757">synchronized</code>: mutual exclusion. <code data-start="3777" data-end="3787">volatile</code>: visibility guarantee.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3813" data-end="3937" class="">
<p data-start="3817" data-end="3937" class=""><strong data-start="3817" data-end="3871">What is the difference between process and thread?</strong><br data-start="3871" data-end="3874">
<em data-start="3877" data-end="3937">Process: independent execution. Thread: part of a process.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3939" data-end="4037" class="">
<p data-start="3943" data-end="4037" class=""><strong data-start="3943" data-end="3964">What is deadlock?</strong><br data-start="3964" data-end="3967">
<em data-start="3970" data-end="4037">When two threads wait forever on each other to release resources.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4039" data-end="4126" class="">
<p data-start="4043" data-end="4126" class=""><strong data-start="4043" data-end="4078">How to create a thread in Java?</strong><br data-start="4078" data-end="4081">
<em data-start="4084" data-end="4126">Extend <code data-start="4092" data-end="4100">Thread</code> or implement <code data-start="4114" data-end="4124">Runnable</code>.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4128" data-end="4245" class="">
<p data-start="4132" data-end="4245" class=""><strong data-start="4132" data-end="4167">What is the Executor framework?</strong><br data-start="4167" data-end="4170">
<em data-start="4173" data-end="4245">Provides a high-level replacement for thread management (thread pool).</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4247" data-end="4363" class="">
<p data-start="4251" data-end="4363" class=""><strong data-start="4251" data-end="4285">What is the Java Memory Model?</strong><br data-start="4285" data-end="4288">
<em data-start="4291" data-end="4363">Defines how threads interact through memory — crucial for concurrency.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4365" data-end="4490" class="">
<p data-start="4369" data-end="4490" class=""><strong data-start="4369" data-end="4408">What is garbage collection in Java?</strong><br data-start="4408" data-end="4411">
<em data-start="4414" data-end="4490">Automatic memory management that reclaims memory from unreachable objects.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4492" data-end="4628" class="">
<p data-start="4496" data-end="4628" class=""><strong data-start="4496" data-end="4552">What are strong, weak, soft, and phantom references?</strong><br data-start="4552" data-end="4555">
<em data-start="4558" data-end="4628">Different reference strengths affecting garbage collection behavior.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4630" data-end="4731" class="">
<p data-start="4634" data-end="4731" class=""><strong data-start="4634" data-end="4663">What are lambdas in Java?</strong><br data-start="4663" data-end="4666">
<em data-start="4669" data-end="4731">Anonymous functions introduced in Java 8: <code data-start="4712" data-end="4729">(a, b) -&gt; a + b</code>.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="4733" data-end="4736" class="">
<h3 data-start="4738" data-end="4762" class=""><strong data-start="4742" data-end="4762">Java 8+ Features</strong></h3>
<ol start="41" data-start="4764" data-end="5300">
<li data-start="4764" data-end="4876" class="">
<p data-start="4768" data-end="4876" class=""><strong data-start="4768" data-end="4797">What are Streams in Java?</strong><br data-start="4797" data-end="4800">
<em data-start="4803" data-end="4876">Functional-style operations on collections (e.g., filter, map, reduce).</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4878" data-end="4959" class="">
<p data-start="4882" data-end="4959" class=""><strong data-start="4882" data-end="4911">What is Optional in Java?</strong><br data-start="4911" data-end="4914">
<em data-start="4917" data-end="4959">A container object to avoid null checks.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4961" data-end="5087" class="">
<p data-start="4965" data-end="5087" class=""><strong data-start="4965" data-end="5020">What is the difference between <code data-start="4998" data-end="5003">map</code> and <code data-start="5008" data-end="5017">flatMap</code>?</strong><br data-start="5020" data-end="5023">
<em data-start="5026" data-end="5087"><code data-start="5027" data-end="5032">map</code> transforms values. <code data-start="5052" data-end="5061">flatMap</code> flattens nested streams.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5089" data-end="5202" class="">
<p data-start="5093" data-end="5202" class=""><strong data-start="5093" data-end="5126">What is Functional Interface?</strong><br data-start="5126" data-end="5129">
<em data-start="5132" data-end="5202">Interface with a single abstract method (e.g., Runnable, Predicate).</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5204" data-end="5300" class="">
<p data-start="5208" data-end="5300" class=""><strong data-start="5208" data-end="5237">What is method reference?</strong><br data-start="5237" data-end="5240">
<em data-start="5243" data-end="5300">Shorthand for calling methods: <code data-start="5275" data-end="5298">ClassName::methodName</code>.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="5302" data-end="5305" class="">
<h3 data-start="5307" data-end="5341" class=""><strong data-start="5311" data-end="5341">Miscellaneous / Real World</strong></h3>
<ol start="46" data-start="5343" data-end="5944">
<li data-start="5343" data-end="5426" class="">
<p data-start="5347" data-end="5426" class=""><strong data-start="5347" data-end="5384">How to handle exceptions in Java?</strong><br data-start="5384" data-end="5387">
<em data-start="5390" data-end="5426">Using try-catch-finally or throws.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5428" data-end="5540" class="">
<p data-start="5432" data-end="5540" class=""><strong data-start="5432" data-end="5468">Checked vs Unchecked exceptions?</strong><br data-start="5468" data-end="5471">
<em data-start="5474" data-end="5540">Checked: checked at compile time. Unchecked: runtime exceptions.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5542" data-end="5714" class="">
<p data-start="5546" data-end="5714" class=""><strong data-start="5546" data-end="5621">What is the difference between String, StringBuffer, and StringBuilder?</strong><br data-start="5621" data-end="5624">
<em data-start="5627" data-end="5714">String: immutable. StringBuffer: thread-safe. StringBuilder: faster, not thread-safe.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5716" data-end="5800" class="">
<p data-start="5720" data-end="5800" class=""><strong data-start="5720" data-end="5754">What is the Singleton pattern?</strong><br data-start="5754" data-end="5757">
<em data-start="5760" data-end="5800">Ensures a class has only one instance.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5802" data-end="5944" class="">
<p data-start="5806" data-end="5944" class=""><strong data-start="5806" data-end="5853">Best practices for writing clean Java code?</strong><br data-start="5853" data-end="5856">
<em data-start="5859" data-end="5944">Follow SOLID principles, use streams wisely, prefer immutability, write unit tests.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="5946" data-end="5949" class="">

light"><p data-start="0" data-end="232" class="">Great! Here's a comprehensive set of <strong data-start="37" data-end="80">50 SQL interview questions with answers</strong>, ranging from beginner to advanced levels — especially helpful for backend developers like you working with PostgreSQL or similar relational databases:</p>
<hr data-start="234" data-end="237" class="">
<h3 data-start="239" data-end="264" class=""> <strong data-start="246" data-end="264">Beginner Level</strong></h3>
<ol data-start="266" data-end="1309">
<li data-start="266" data-end="365" class="">
<p data-start="269" data-end="365" class=""><strong data-start="269" data-end="285">What is SQL?</strong><br data-start="285" data-end="288">
<em data-start="291" data-end="365">Structured Query Language used to communicate with relational databases.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="367" data-end="476" class="">
<p data-start="370" data-end="476" class=""><strong data-start="370" data-end="396">What is a primary key?</strong><br data-start="396" data-end="399">
<em data-start="402" data-end="476">A column or set of columns that uniquely identifies each row in a table.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="478" data-end="600" class="">
<p data-start="481" data-end="600" class=""><strong data-start="481" data-end="507">What is a foreign key?</strong><br data-start="507" data-end="510">
<em data-start="513" data-end="600">A column that refers to the primary key of another table to establish a relationship.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="602" data-end="741" class="">
<p data-start="605" data-end="741" class=""><strong data-start="605" data-end="661">What is the difference between <code data-start="638" data-end="645">WHERE</code> and <code data-start="650" data-end="658">HAVING</code>?</strong><br data-start="661" data-end="664">
<em data-start="667" data-end="741"><code data-start="668" data-end="675">WHERE</code> filters rows before grouping, <code data-start="706" data-end="714">HAVING</code> filters after <code data-start="729" data-end="739">GROUP BY</code>.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="743" data-end="837" class="">
<p data-start="746" data-end="837" class=""><strong data-start="746" data-end="765">What is a join?</strong><br data-start="765" data-end="768">
<em data-start="771" data-end="837">Combines rows from two or more tables based on a related column.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="839" data-end="919" class="">
<p data-start="842" data-end="919" class=""><strong data-start="842" data-end="868">Types of joins in SQL?</strong><br data-start="868" data-end="871">
<em data-start="874" data-end="919">INNER, LEFT, RIGHT, FULL OUTER, CROSS JOIN.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="921" data-end="1072" class="">
<p data-start="924" data-end="1072" class=""><strong data-start="924" data-end="988">What is the difference between <code data-start="957" data-end="969">INNER JOIN</code> and <code data-start="974" data-end="985">LEFT JOIN</code>?</strong><br data-start="988" data-end="991">
<em data-start="994" data-end="1072"><code data-start="995" data-end="1007">INNER JOIN</code>: matches only. <code data-start="1023" data-end="1034">LEFT JOIN</code>: all from left + matched from right.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1074" data-end="1145" class="">
<p data-start="1077" data-end="1145" class=""><strong data-start="1077" data-end="1102">What is a NULL value?</strong><br data-start="1102" data-end="1105">
<em data-start="1108" data-end="1145">Represents missing or unknown data.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1147" data-end="1217" class="">
<p data-start="1150" data-end="1217" class=""><strong data-start="1150" data-end="1178">How to filter out NULLs?</strong><br data-start="1178" data-end="1181">
<em data-start="1184" data-end="1217">Use <code data-start="1189" data-end="1198">IS NULL</code> or <code data-start="1202" data-end="1215">IS NOT NULL</code>.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1219" data-end="1309" class="">
<p data-start="1223" data-end="1309" class=""><strong data-start="1223" data-end="1258">What does <code data-start="1235" data-end="1252">SELECT DISTINCT</code> do?</strong><br data-start="1258" data-end="1261">
<em data-start="1264" data-end="1309">Removes duplicate rows from the result set.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="1311" data-end="1314" class="">
<h3 data-start="1316" data-end="1345" class=""> <strong data-start="1323" data-end="1345">Intermediate Level</strong></h3>
<ol start="11" data-start="1347" data-end="2489">
<li data-start="1347" data-end="1441" class="">
<p data-start="1351" data-end="1441" class=""><strong data-start="1351" data-end="1377">What is normalization?</strong><br data-start="1377" data-end="1380">
<em data-start="1383" data-end="1441">Process to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1443" data-end="1562" class="">
<p data-start="1447" data-end="1562" class=""><strong data-start="1447" data-end="1477">What are the normal forms?</strong><br data-start="1477" data-end="1480">
<em data-start="1483" data-end="1562">1NF, 2NF, 3NF (and more): each has specific rules to structure data properly.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1564" data-end="1664" class="">
<p data-start="1568" data-end="1664" class=""><strong data-start="1568" data-end="1591">What is a subquery?</strong><br data-start="1591" data-end="1594">
<em data-start="1597" data-end="1664">A query inside another query. Can be used in SELECT, WHERE, FROM.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1666" data-end="1765" class="">
<p data-start="1670" data-end="1765" class=""><strong data-start="1670" data-end="1704">What is a correlated subquery?</strong><br data-start="1704" data-end="1707">
<em data-start="1710" data-end="1765">A subquery that refers to columns in the outer query.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1767" data-end="1919" class="">
<p data-start="1771" data-end="1919" class=""><strong data-start="1771" data-end="1821">Difference between <code data-start="1792" data-end="1796">IN</code>, <code data-start="1798" data-end="1806">EXISTS</code>, and <code data-start="1812" data-end="1818">JOIN</code>?</strong><br data-start="1821" data-end="1824">
<em data-start="1827" data-end="1919"><code data-start="1828" data-end="1832">IN</code>: returns values from a list. <code data-start="1862" data-end="1870">EXISTS</code>: checks for existence. <code data-start="1894" data-end="1900">JOIN</code>: combines tables.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1921" data-end="2038" class="">
<p data-start="1925" data-end="2038" class=""><strong data-start="1925" data-end="1957">What is a <code data-start="1937" data-end="1947">GROUP BY</code> clause?</strong><br data-start="1957" data-end="1960">
<em data-start="1963" data-end="2038">Groups rows with the same values for aggregate functions like COUNT, SUM.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2040" data-end="2139" class="">
<p data-start="2044" data-end="2139" class=""><strong data-start="2044" data-end="2077">What are aggregate functions?</strong><br data-start="2077" data-end="2080">
<em data-start="2083" data-end="2139">COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX — operate on sets of values.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2141" data-end="2223" class="">
<p data-start="2145" data-end="2223" class=""><strong data-start="2145" data-end="2164">What is a view?</strong><br data-start="2164" data-end="2167">
<em data-start="2170" data-end="2223">A virtual table based on the result set of a query.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2225" data-end="2400" class="">
<p data-start="2229" data-end="2400" class=""><strong data-start="2229" data-end="2297">What is the difference between <code data-start="2262" data-end="2270">DELETE</code>, <code data-start="2272" data-end="2282">TRUNCATE</code>, and <code data-start="2288" data-end="2294">DROP</code>?</strong><br data-start="2297" data-end="2300">
<em data-start="2303" data-end="2400"><code data-start="2304" data-end="2312">DELETE</code>: removes rows with WHERE. <code data-start="2339" data-end="2349">TRUNCATE</code>: removes all rows, faster. <code data-start="2377" data-end="2383">DROP</code>: removes table.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2402" data-end="2489" class="">
<p data-start="2406" data-end="2489" class=""><strong data-start="2406" data-end="2427">What is indexing?</strong><br data-start="2427" data-end="2430">
<em data-start="2433" data-end="2489">Improves query speed by allowing quick lookup of data.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="2491" data-end="2494" class="">
<h3 data-start="2496" data-end="2521" class=""> <strong data-start="2503" data-end="2521">Advanced Level</strong></h3>
<ol start="21" data-start="2523" data-end="3570">
<li data-start="2523" data-end="2609" class="">
<p data-start="2527" data-end="2609" class=""><strong data-start="2527" data-end="2555">What is a composite key?</strong><br data-start="2555" data-end="2558">
<em data-start="2561" data-end="2609">A primary key made up of more than one column.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2611" data-end="2673" class="">
<p data-start="2615" data-end="2673" class=""><strong data-start="2615" data-end="2639">What is a self join?</strong><br data-start="2639" data-end="2642">
<em data-start="2645" data-end="2673">Joining a table to itself.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2675" data-end="2800" class="">
<p data-start="2679" data-end="2800" class=""><strong data-start="2679" data-end="2715">How do transactions work in SQL?</strong><br data-start="2715" data-end="2718">
<em data-start="2721" data-end="2800">A group of queries executed together using <code data-start="2765" data-end="2772">BEGIN</code>, <code data-start="2774" data-end="2782">COMMIT</code>, and <code data-start="2788" data-end="2798">ROLLBACK</code>.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2802" data-end="2919" class="">
<p data-start="2806" data-end="2919" class=""><strong data-start="2806" data-end="2836">What is ACID in databases?</strong><br data-start="2836" data-end="2839">
<em data-start="2842" data-end="2919">Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability — key transaction properties.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2921" data-end="3004" class="">
<p data-start="2925" data-end="3004" class=""><strong data-start="2925" data-end="2956">What is a stored procedure?</strong><br data-start="2956" data-end="2959">
<em data-start="2962" data-end="3004">Precompiled SQL code that can be reused.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3006" data-end="3106" class="">
<p data-start="3010" data-end="3106" class=""><strong data-start="3010" data-end="3032">What are triggers?</strong><br data-start="3032" data-end="3035">
<em data-start="3038" data-end="3106">Procedures automatically invoked on INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE events.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3108" data-end="3232" class="">
<p data-start="3112" data-end="3232" class=""><strong data-start="3112" data-end="3156">What is a common table expression (CTE)?</strong><br data-start="3156" data-end="3159">
<em data-start="3162" data-end="3232">A temporary result set defined with <code data-start="3199" data-end="3205">WITH</code> keyword, used in a query.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3234" data-end="3350" class="">
<p data-start="3238" data-end="3350" class=""><strong data-start="3238" data-end="3285">Difference between <code data-start="3259" data-end="3266">UNION</code> and <code data-start="3271" data-end="3282">UNION ALL</code>?</strong><br data-start="3285" data-end="3288">
<em data-start="3291" data-end="3350"><code data-start="3292" data-end="3299">UNION</code>: removes duplicates. <code data-start="3321" data-end="3332">UNION ALL</code>: keeps all rows.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3352" data-end="3487" class="">
<p data-start="3356" data-end="3487" class=""><strong data-start="3356" data-end="3386">What is a window function?</strong><br data-start="3386" data-end="3389">
<em data-start="3392" data-end="3487">Performs calculations across rows related to the current row, e.g., <code data-start="3461" data-end="3469">RANK()</code>, <code data-start="3471" data-end="3485">ROW_NUMBER()</code>.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3489" data-end="3570" class="">
<p data-start="3493" data-end="3570" class=""><strong data-start="3493" data-end="3533">What is the <code data-start="3507" data-end="3513">CASE</code> statement in SQL?</strong><br data-start="3533" data-end="3536">
<em data-start="3539" data-end="3570">If-else logic in SQL queries.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="3572" data-end="3575" class="">
<h3 data-start="3577" data-end="3614" class="">⚙️ <strong data-start="3584" data-end="3614">Performance &amp; Optimization</strong></h3>
<ol start="31" data-start="3616" data-end="4208">
<li data-start="3616" data-end="3745" class="">
<p data-start="3620" data-end="3745" class=""><strong data-start="3620" data-end="3657">How to optimize a slow SQL query?</strong><br data-start="3657" data-end="3660">
<em data-start="3663" data-end="3745">Use indexing, avoid <code data-start="3684" data-end="3694">SELECT *</code>, analyze execution plan, reduce joins/subqueries.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3747" data-end="3876" class="">
<p data-start="3751" data-end="3876" class=""><strong data-start="3751" data-end="3798">What is a clustered vs non-clustered index?</strong><br data-start="3798" data-end="3801">
<em data-start="3804" data-end="3876">Clustered: sorts actual data. Non-clustered: stores a pointer to data.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3878" data-end="3989" class="">
<p data-start="3882" data-end="3989" class=""><strong data-start="3882" data-end="3910">What is denormalization?</strong><br data-start="3910" data-end="3913">
<em data-start="3916" data-end="3989">Adding redundancy for read performance at the cost of write complexity.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="3991" data-end="4092" class="">
<p data-start="3995" data-end="4092" class=""><strong data-start="3995" data-end="4040">How does indexing affect inserts/updates?</strong><br data-start="4040" data-end="4043">
<em data-start="4046" data-end="4092">Can slow them down due to index maintenance.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4094" data-end="4208" class="">
<p data-start="4098" data-end="4208" class=""><strong data-start="4098" data-end="4128">What is an execution plan?</strong><br data-start="4128" data-end="4131">
<em data-start="4134" data-end="4208">Details how the database executes a query — used for performance tuning.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="4210" data-end="4213" class="">

<hr data-start="4934" data-end="4937" class="">
<h3 data-start="4939" data-end="4979" class=""> <strong data-start="4946" data-end="4979">Tricky / Conceptual Questions</strong></h3>
<ol start="41" data-start="4981" data-end="5204">
<li data-start="4981" data-end="5086" class="">
<p data-start="4985" data-end="5086" class=""><strong data-start="4985" data-end="5028">Can a table have multiple primary keys?</strong><br data-start="5028" data-end="5031">
<em data-start="5034" data-end="5086">No. Only one primary key, but it can be composite.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5088" data-end="5154" class="">
<p data-start="5092" data-end="5154" class=""><strong data-start="5092" data-end="5122">Can a foreign key be null?</strong><br data-start="5122" data-end="5125">
<em data-start="5128" data-end="5154">Yes, if it allows nulls.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5156" data-end="5204" class="">
<p data-start="5160" data-end="5204" class=""><strong data-start="5160" data-end="5202">How to calculate running total in SQL?</strong></p>
</li>
</ol>

 </span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">SUM</span></span><span>(salary) </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">OVER</span></span><span> (</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">ORDER</span></span><span> </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">BY</span></span><span> name) </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">AS</span></span><span> running_total

<ol start="44" data-start="5320" data-end="6049">
<li data-start="5320" data-end="5448" class="">
<p data-start="5324" data-end="5448" class=""><strong data-start="5324" data-end="5370">Difference between delete and soft delete?</strong><br data-start="5370" data-end="5373">
<em data-start="5376" data-end="5448">Soft delete marks a row as inactive instead of removing it physically.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5450" data-end="5543" class="">
<p data-start="5454" data-end="5543" class=""><strong data-start="5454" data-end="5490">What is the use of <code data-start="5475" data-end="5487">COALESCE()</code>?</strong><br data-start="5490" data-end="5493">
<em data-start="5496" data-end="5543">Returns the first non-null value in the list.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5545" data-end="5638" class="">
<p data-start="5549" data-end="5638" class=""><strong data-start="5549" data-end="5583">What is <code data-start="5559" data-end="5566">NVL()</code> or <code data-start="5570" data-end="5580">IFNULL()</code>?</strong><br data-start="5583" data-end="5586">
<em data-start="5589" data-end="5638">Functions to replace NULL with a default value.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5640" data-end="5721" class="">
<p data-start="5644" data-end="5721" class=""><strong data-start="5644" data-end="5686">What is the default sort order in SQL?</strong><br data-start="5686" data-end="5689">
<em data-start="5692" data-end="5721">Ascending (ASC) by default.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5723" data-end="5825" class="">
<p data-start="5727" data-end="5825" class=""><strong data-start="5727" data-end="5767">Can we use <code data-start="5740" data-end="5750">ORDER BY</code> in subqueries?</strong><br data-start="5767" data-end="5770">
<em data-start="5773" data-end="5825">Only if it’s used with <code data-start="5797" data-end="5802">TOP</code>, <code data-start="5804" data-end="5811">LIMIT</code>, or <code data-start="5816" data-end="5823">FETCH</code>.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5827" data-end="5942" class="">
<p data-start="5831" data-end="5942" class=""><strong data-start="5831" data-end="5859">What are surrogate keys?</strong><br data-start="5859" data-end="5862">
<em data-start="5865" data-end="5942">Artificial keys (like auto-increment ID) not derived from application data.</em></p>
</li>
<li data-start="5944" data-end="6049" class="">
<p data-start="5948" data-end="6049" class=""><strong data-start="5948" data-end="6001">Can we use aggregate functions in <code data-start="5984" data-end="5991">WHERE</code> clause?</strong><br data-start="6001" data-end="6004">
<em data-start="6007" data-end="6049">No, use them in <code data-start="6024" data-end="6032">HAVING</code> clause instead.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>

Here are 50 Spring Security interview questions with answers, covering basic to advanced topics:

Basic Level

  1. What is Spring Security?
    Spring Security is a powerful and customizable authentication and access-control framework for Java applications.

  2. How is Spring Security different from JAAS?
    JAAS is part of Java EE, whereas Spring Security is part of the Spring ecosystem with better integration and flexibility.

  3. What are the main features of Spring Security?
    Authentication, Authorization, Password Management, CSRF protection, Session Management, and integration with OAuth2 and JWT.

  4. How does Spring Security work internally?
    It uses servlet filters to intercept and process security logic for HTTP requests.

  5. What is the role of SecurityFilterChain?
    It defines how incoming HTTP requests are filtered and authenticated/authorized.

  6. What is the UserDetails interface?
    It provides core user information like username, password, and authorities.

  7. What is the UserDetailsService?
    It’s a service interface used to fetch user details from a data source.

  8. What is the PasswordEncoder interface?
    It’s used to encode passwords securely (e.g., using BCrypt).

  9. How to configure in-memory authentication in Spring Security?
    Using InMemoryUserDetailsManager and AuthenticationManagerBuilder.

  10. How to configure Spring Security with a custom login page?
    Override default login using .loginPage("/customLogin") in the config.

Intermediate Level

  1. What is CSRF? How does Spring Security handle it?
    CSRF is a type of attack that tricks the user into executing unwanted actions. Spring adds a CSRF token to requests to prevent this.

  2. How to disable CSRF in Spring Security?

java
http.csrf().disable();

  1. What is the difference between @Secured and @PreAuthorize?
    @Secured supports only role checks; @PreAuthorize supports SpEL for complex expressions.

  2. What is the difference between hasRole() and hasAuthority()?
    hasRole() automatically adds "ROLE_" prefix; hasAuthority() checks the exact authority.

  3. How do you secure REST APIs in Spring Security?
    Use stateless authentication with JWT, configure HTTP security accordingly.

  4. How to implement JWT-based authentication in Spring Security?
    Intercept requests using filters, validate JWT, extract user details and authenticate manually.

  5. How to define multiple user roles?
    Assign roles/authorities in the user object and secure endpoints with hasRole("ROLE_NAME").

  6. How does method-level security work in Spring Security?
    By enabling @EnableGlobalMethodSecurity(prePostEnabled = true).

  7. How to use custom UserDetailsService?
    Implement the interface and override loadUserByUsername().

  8. How to handle access denied in Spring Security?
    Use .exceptionHandling().accessDeniedHandler() to customize behavior.

Advanced Level

  1. What is AuthenticationManager?
    It is responsible for processing an authentication request.

  2. What is the role of AuthenticationProvider?
    It performs the actual authentication and returns an authenticated token.

  3. How to implement a custom AuthenticationProvider?
    Implement the interface and override authenticate() and supports().

  4. What are security headers in Spring Security?
    They are HTTP headers like XSS protection, Content-Security-Policy added automatically.

  5. How to secure endpoints with different roles?

java
.authorizeRequests()
    .antMatchers("/admin/**").hasRole("ADMIN")
    .antMatchers("/user/**").hasRole("USER");

  1. What is the difference between form-based and basic authentication?
    Form-based shows an HTML form; basic uses browser popup and HTTP headers.

  2. How to handle session management?
    Using .sessionManagement() with options like stateless, invalidSessionUrl, max sessions, etc.

  3. What is stateless authentication?
    No session is created; each request is authenticated (e.g., using JWT).

  4. What is SecurityContextHolder?
    It holds security context for the current thread (authenticated user details).

  5. How to implement remember-me functionality?
    Use .rememberMe() in your security config and configure token validity and key.

OAuth2 and JWT Integration

  1. How does Spring Security support OAuth2?
    Spring Security provides OAuth2 client and resource server support with configurations.

  2. What are the components of JWT?
    Header, Payload, and Signature.

  3. How to decode a JWT?
    Using libraries like io.jsonwebtoken (JJWT) or java-jwt.

  4. How to validate a JWT in Spring Security?
    Extract token from header, parse it, and validate signature and expiration.

  5. How to store roles in JWT?
    Add roles as claims and parse them into authorities in the filter.

  6. How to integrate Keycloak with Spring Security?
    Use Spring Boot adapter or OpenID Connect support with Keycloak config.

  7. What is the use of BearerTokenAuthenticationFilter?
    It processes bearer tokens (like JWT) for API authentication.

  8. How to refresh JWT tokens?
    Implement an endpoint that checks the refresh token and issues a new access token.

  9. Difference between Access Token and Refresh Token?
    Access token is short-lived and used for requests; refresh token is used to get a new access token.

  10. Can Spring Security support multi-tenant authentication?
    Yes, using a custom UserDetailsService or different authentication providers per tenant.

Testing and Best Practices

  1. How to test Spring Security configuration?
    Use @WithMockUser, @WithUserDetails, or SecurityMockMvcRequestPostProcessors.

  2. What is SecurityContextPersistenceFilter?
    It loads and stores the SecurityContext between requests.

  3. What is GrantedAuthority?
    It represents a permission or role granted to the user.

  4. How to secure static resources in Spring Security?
    Exclude them using .requestMatchers("/css/**", "/js/**").permitAll().

  5. How to allow access to specific IPs only?
    Use hasIpAddress("192.168.1.0/24") in SpEL.

  6. How to handle CORS in Spring Security?
    Use http.cors() and define a CorsConfigurationSource bean.

  7. What is XSS and how does Spring Security prevent it?
    Cross-site scripting attack; Spring uses HTTP headers and input validation.

  8. How to use multiple SecurityFilterChains?
    Define beans with @Order annotations for each URL pattern.

  9. How to implement two-factor authentication in Spring Security?
    Custom filter or flow after login to verify OTP or email code.

  10. What is the default login endpoint in Spring Security?
    /login is the default login URL for form-based login.

Let me know if you want a PDF or categorized version (e.g., REST API-focused, JWT-focused).

You said:
Now its time for multithreding
ChatGPT said:

Great! Here's a list of 50 multithreading interview questions with answers, ranging from basic to advanced:

Basic Level

  1. What is a thread in Java?
    A thread is a lightweight subprocess, the smallest unit of execution.

  2. What is the difference between process and thread?
    A process is an independent program, whereas a thread is a smaller part of a process.

  3. How can you create a thread in Java?
    By extending Thread class or implementing Runnable interface.

  4. Which is better: Runnable or Thread?
    Runnable is better for reusability and when multiple threads share the same object.

  5. What is the lifecycle of a thread?
    New → Runnable → Running → Waiting/Blocked → Terminated.

  6. What does start() method do?
    It creates a new thread and calls the run() method internally.

  7. What happens if you call run() directly instead of start()?
    It runs in the current thread, not in a new one.

  8. What is the use of Thread.sleep()?
    It pauses the execution of the thread for a specified time.

  9. What is Thread.yield()?
    It hints the scheduler that the current thread is willing to yield its current use of the CPU.

  10. What is Thread.join()?
    It waits for a thread to die before proceeding further.

Intermediate Level

  1. What is synchronization in Java?
    It’s a mechanism to control access to shared resources by multiple threads.

  2. What is a synchronized block?
    A block of code that is locked on a particular object monitor.

  3. What is the difference between synchronized method and synchronized block?
    Method locks the entire method; block locks a specific section or object.

  4. What is a deadlock?
    A condition where two or more threads are blocked forever, waiting on each other.

  5. How to prevent deadlock?
    Avoid nested locks, use lock ordering, or use tryLock with timeout.

  6. What is race condition?
    When two threads access shared data at the same time, leading to unexpected behavior.

  7. What is reentrant synchronization?
    It allows the thread to acquire the same lock multiple times.

  8. What is the use of volatile keyword?
    It ensures visibility of changes to variables across threads.

  9. What is AtomicInteger and why is it used?
    A class that provides atomic operations on integers without synchronization.

  10. Difference between wait() and sleep()?
    wait() releases the lock and is used for communication between threads; sleep() just pauses the thread.

Concurrency Utilities

  1. What is the java.util.concurrent package?
    It contains concurrency utilities like ExecutorService, CountDownLatch, Semaphore, etc.

  2. What is ExecutorService?
    A high-level replacement for managing thread lifecycle and execution.

  3. How to create a thread pool in Java?
    Using Executors.newFixedThreadPool(), newCachedThreadPool(), etc.

  4. What is Callable vs Runnable?
    Callable returns a value and can throw an exception; Runnable does not.

  5. What is Future in Java?
    Represents the result of an asynchronous computation.

  6. What is CountDownLatch?
    A synchronization aid that allows threads to wait until a set of operations are completed.

  7. What is CyclicBarrier?
    A barrier that allows a set of threads to wait for each other to reach a common point.

  8. What is Semaphore?
    Controls access to a resource by multiple threads using permits.

  9. What is ReentrantLock?
    An explicit lock with more control compared to synchronized blocks.

  10. What is ReadWriteLock?
    Allows multiple readers or one writer thread at a time.

Advanced Level

  1. What is thread starvation?
    When a thread is unable to gain regular access to shared resources.

  2. What is thread priority in Java?
    A hint to the thread scheduler about the importance of the thread (1 to 10).

  3. What is the default thread priority?
    5 (NORM_PRIORITY).

  4. What is a daemon thread?
    A background thread that dies when all user threads are finished.

  5. How to create a daemon thread?
    Call setDaemon(true) before starting the thread.

  6. What is the difference between live lock and deadlock?
    In live lock, threads keep changing state in response to each other without progress.

  7. What is the difference between Thread and Runnable in terms of resource sharing?
    Runnable can be shared between multiple threads; Thread class cannot.

  8. What are thread-safe collections in Java?
    Collections like ConcurrentHashMap, CopyOnWriteArrayList, etc.

  9. What is ThreadLocal in Java?
    It provides thread-local variables — each thread has its own copy.

  10. What is the difference between synchronized and Lock interface?
    Lock offers more flexibility (e.g., tryLock, interruptible locks).

Best Practices and Design Patterns

  1. How to handle exceptions in threads?
    Use Thread.setUncaughtExceptionHandler() or try-catch in run().

  2. What is the Producer-Consumer problem?
    A classic example of a multi-threading problem using wait-notify.

  3. What is the Fork/Join framework?
    Used for parallel processing by breaking tasks into subtasks recursively.

  4. What is the double-checked locking idiom?
    A pattern to reduce the overhead of acquiring a lock by first checking condition without locking.

  5. What is the significance of final with threads?
    Makes variables thread-safe by ensuring they are initialized only once.

  6. What is false sharing?
    When threads on different processors modify variables close together in memory, causing cache invalidation.

  7. How to make Singleton thread-safe?
    Using synchronized, eager initialization, or enum.

  8. What is busy waiting?
    When a thread continuously checks a condition without releasing CPU.

  9. What are interruptible and non-interruptible methods?
    Methods like sleep(), wait() are interruptible; synchronized blocks are not.

  10. Why should you avoid using Thread.stop()?
    It is unsafe and deprecated as it can leave shared data in an inconsistent state.

Here are 50 REST API interview questions with answers, from basics to advanced levels:

Basic Level

  1. What is a REST API?
    REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for designing networked applications using HTTP.

  2. What are the main HTTP methods used in REST?
    GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE.

  3. What is the difference between PUT and PATCH?
    PUT replaces the entire resource, while PATCH updates a part of the resource.

  4. What is the difference between GET and POST?
    GET retrieves data; POST submits data to be processed.

  5. What are resources in REST?
    Resources are entities (e.g., User, Product) identified by URIs.

  6. What is a URI?
    Uniform Resource Identifier – the address of a resource.

  7. What is the difference between URI and URL?
    URL is a type of URI that includes location (protocol + address).

  8. What is Idempotency?
    An operation is idempotent if it produces the same result no matter how many times it is called.

  9. Which HTTP methods are idempotent?
    GET, PUT, DELETE, and HEAD.

  10. What status code means success?
    200 OK.

Intermediate Level

  1. What does 201 Created mean?
    A new resource has been created successfully.

  2. What does 204 No Content mean?
    The request was successful but there is no content to return.

  3. What is the difference between 400 and 404?
    400 is a bad request; 404 is resource not found.

  4. What is 500 Internal Server Error?
    A generic error when the server fails unexpectedly.

  5. What is HATEOAS?
    Hypermedia as the Engine of Application State – REST responses contain links to other actions/resources.

  6. What is content negotiation in REST?
    Allows clients to request specific content types (like JSON, XML) using Accept headers.

  7. How do you handle versioning in REST APIs?
    Via URI (e.g., /v1/users), headers, query params, or content negotiation.

  8. What are HTTP headers?
    Metadata sent with HTTP requests/responses (e.g., Content-Type, Authorization).

  9. What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous APIs?
    Synchronous waits for a response; asynchronous returns immediately and handles later.

  10. What is OpenAPI/Swagger?
    A tool to document and test REST APIs.

Spring Boot REST API Specific

  1. How to create a REST controller in Spring Boot?
    Using @RestController annotation.

  2. How to map a request in Spring Boot?
    Using @RequestMapping, @GetMapping, @PostMapping, etc.

  3. How to get data from URL parameters?
    Use @PathVariable or @RequestParam.

  4. How to send data in a POST request body?
    Use @RequestBody.

  5. How to return a custom HTTP status?
    Use ResponseEntity.

  6. What is @ExceptionHandler used for?
    To handle exceptions globally or in a controller.

  7. What is the purpose of @CrossOrigin?
    To allow cross-origin requests (CORS support).

  8. What is the difference between @RestController and @Controller?
    @RestController = @Controller + @ResponseBody by default.

  9. How to validate request data in Spring Boot?
    Use JSR-303 annotations like @Valid or @NotNull.

  10. How to secure REST APIs?
    Using Spring Security + JWT or OAuth2.

Advanced Level

  1. What are best practices for designing REST APIs?
    Use nouns for resources, version your API, handle errors properly, use HTTP methods correctly.

  2. What is pagination and how is it implemented?
    Breaking data into pages using query params like ?page=1&size=10.

  3. What is rate limiting?
    Restricting the number of requests a client can make in a given time frame.

  4. What is throttling?
    Controlling the usage of APIs for each user or service.

  5. How to handle errors in REST APIs?
    Use consistent error response format with appropriate status codes and messages.

  6. What are common status codes for client errors?
    400 (Bad Request), 401 (Unauthorized), 403 (Forbidden), 404 (Not Found).

  7. What is JWT and how is it used in REST APIs?
    JWT (JSON Web Token) is used for stateless authentication by passing tokens in headers.

  8. What is an API gateway?
    A single entry point for all clients to access backend services securely.

  9. How to test REST APIs?
    Use tools like Postman, curl, Swagger UI.

  10. How do you cache REST responses?
    Use HTTP headers like Cache-Control, ETag, or use server-side caching.

Real-World & Design

  1. How do you handle file uploads in REST APIs?
    Use @RequestParam("file") MultipartFile file in Spring Boot.

  2. How do you handle authentication in REST APIs?
    Using JWT, OAuth2, API Keys, or session tokens.

  3. What are RESTful constraints?
    Client-server, stateless, cacheable, layered system, uniform interface, code on demand (optional).

  4. How to make REST APIs idempotent?
    Avoid side effects and always return the same response for repeated calls.

  5. What is HAL (Hypertext Application Language)?
    A format that enables linking resources in REST APIs.

  6. What are the disadvantages of REST APIs?
    Statelessness can lead to more data sent per request, less suitable for real-time communication.

  7. What is a DTO in REST?
    Data Transfer Object – used to transfer data between client and server, separate from entities.

  8. How do you handle concurrency in REST APIs?
    Use optimistic locking with versioning or timestamps.

  9. What are the challenges in REST API security?
    Token theft, injection attacks, unauthorized access – mitigate with HTTPS, validation, security headers.

  10. When should you use REST vs gRPC or GraphQL?
    REST is better for simplicity and web compatibility; gRPC for high-performance microservices; GraphQL for flexible querying.

Let me know if you’d like code examples or a version focused on Spring Boot implementation, JWT, or microservices REST patterns.

1. Authentication Failure → 401 Unauthorized

  • Message: "You don't have permission to access this resource."
